passage_text:
US history books have traditionally chronicled the actions of male Revolutionary War <u id="q1">heroes such as</u> George Washington, Paul Revere, and John Paul Jones. Increasingly, such books include accounts of the many brave women <u id="q2">which</u> also contributed—as spies and soldiers—to the effort to gain independence from British rule. 

Deborah Sampson of Plympton, Massachusetts, was <u id="q3"> one of these women.</u>. In 1782, <u id="q4">despite the fact that</u> women weren't allowed to serve in the military, twenty-one-year-old Sampson joined the colonial army. She disguised herself as a man and enlisted under the name of Robert Shurtliff.

<u id="q5">For fourteen months Sampson served in the army, </u> she acted with exceptional bravery and fortitude. Her commanding officers quickly recognized these traits and sent her on several special missions. On <u id="q6">one such</u> mission near West Point, New York, Sampson was part of a scouting party <u id="q7">whose assignment </u> to track and capture a British convoy. While pursuing several British soldiers into a swamp, Sampson was shot in the leg. Fearing that her true identity would be discovered, she did not report to the hospital. Instead, Sampson removed the musket ball by herself.

On another scouting mission, <u id="q8">Sampsons' party,</u> was ambushed by British soldiers. To <u id="q9">escape the scouts</u> had to <u id="q10"> wade across a river.</u> A fierce current swept Sampson into deep waters. <u id="q11">It was the weight of</u> her heavy backpack and musket, Sampson struggled. <u id="q12">For instance, a</u> colonial soldier standing on a sandbar threw her a rope. Summoning her strength, Sampson <u id="q13">plucked from the air that which was to save her</u> and made it to shore.[A] 

Sampson survived the winter and spring with her secret undiscovered. [B] In July 1783, however, she was found out. [C] While this meant that she could no longer
serve in the army, her exemplary record as a soldier was officially recognized. [D] Later, she was awarded a military <u id="q14">pension as</u> a sign of gratitude from the young nation she had helped found.

passage_text:
With a full career in both politics and business, Hiram Fong never set out to develop one of Oahu’s most <u id="q16">spectacularly horticulture</u> attractions. [A] Fong, whose political career spanned over thirty years, was one of the
first two senators from Hawaii <u id="q17">to become </u> a state in 1959 and the first Asian American to serve in the US Senate. Prior to working in politics, Fong paid his own way through Harvard Law School and, upon graduating, <u id="q18">was a part of a</u> law firm. [B] All the while, gardening was his escape.  

<u id="q19">  </u> Wanting <u id="q20">to experiment with </u> growing fruit, he planted bananas, then papaya, lemon, jackfruit, and avocado. [C] By also choosing to plant crops such as bamboo, coconut, betel nut, and turmeric, he <u id="q21"> broadened the types of plants in his garden.</u>. He cultivated slopes covered with ti and pili grassesHe cultivated slopes covered with ti and pili grasses and forests of trees such as kukui, hala, and koa, vegetation <u id="q22">previously an abundance</u> on Oahu. 

After he retired from politics in 1977, Fong continued to oversee his companies, but he focused on gardening, personally importing and planting countless species of plants. Eventually, he divided his land into five gardens, each one named for a US president <u id="q23">whom</u> had served while Fong was a senator. The Eisenhower Plateau is dedicated to native Chinese plants, such as the Hong Kong orchid tree and the Java plum. The Johnson Plateau features exotic fruits. <u id="q24">  </u> Kennedy Valley, with  <u id="q25">its</u> rain forest canopy, <u id="q26">recommends</u> ginger and palms from all over the world. Nixon Valley <u id="q27">will abound </u> with flowers—plumeria, crown flower, and bougainvillea are just a few—while the Ford Plateau highlights hillsides of pili grasses. 

The <u id="q28"> preserve, bearing his name, </u> is now named Senator Fong's Plantation and Gardens, complete with a visitors' center and guided tours. [D] Until his death in 2004 at ninety-seven, Fong spent every weekend tending to his flowers and trees <u id="q29">and a moment to mingle</u> with visitors. He credited gardening for his long, healthy life.

passage_text: Two men ascend the face of Ball’s Pyramid—a rocky island in the Tasman Sea that looks like a mountain jutting up from the waves. The men, Nicholas Carlile and Dean Hiscox, have cameras and flashlights; it is dark. They are heading for a specific melaleuca bush that is hanging 225 feet above the ocean. When they reach it, they find twenty-four enormous black insects. Wingless and up to fifteen inches long, the men see Dryococelus australis —a nocturnal species that had been believed to be extinct for over eighty years. Dryococelus australis, also known as the Lord Howe stick insect, is native to Lord Howe Island, located less than fifteen miles to Ball's Pyramid. [A] The animals thrived on Lord Howe Island until 1918, when a British supply ship ran aground while the ship was being repaired, rats escaped onto the island and quickly wiped out the stick insects. By 1920, the insects were presumed to be extinct. For decades, though the island's remote location and dangerous waters made a thorough search difficult, so the insects' survival wasn't confirmed until 2001.[B] Carlile and Hiscox's find raised a question—what should be done with the rare insects? In 2003, the Australian government permitted the removal of four insects from the island in order to bring the species back in the brink of extinction. [C] Two of the insects were transported to the Melbourne Zoo, where invertebrate conservation expert Patrick Honan, took charge of it.. Starting with only thirty eggs, Honan was able to activate the population of these rare insects. [D] Though the species is now safe, the insects' fame is spreading.. Some stick insects will remain at the zoo as an "insurance population," but the ultimate goal is to reintroduce the insects to their native habitat on Lord Howe Island.
passage_title: Rescuing the Lord Howe Stick Insect

passage_text: Before texting, e-mail, and even the telephone call, there was Morse code. Transmitted over telegraph wire or radio waves via pulses of electric current, Morse code, which was used for over a century, the standard for rapid long-distance communication, especially for those at sea.[A] In 1995, however, the US Coast Guard suspended it's usage of Morse code, including the international distress signal SOS. Despite the speed and precision of technologies such as global positioning satellites, decoding signals in Morse code had become inefficient. To some, the decision signaled the end of Morse code. Morse code’s enduring utility, they argue, lays in the fact that it functions less like a technology then a language—one that can reliably transmit a message under almost any conditions.[B] In Morse code, each letter of the unique Roman alphabet consists of a pattern of short and long signals called dots and dashes.[C] Though Morse code was used longer than any electrical coding system, spelling out and translating messages in Morse code does not require specialized machines. Messages can be transmitted by clicking a flashlight on and off, by flashing a mirror in the sun, or simply blinking. [D] The code can also be spoken aloud, with the words dit and dah substituted for dots and dashes, or rendered rhythmically, allowing people to communicate via handheld buzzers. Because of its versatility, Morse code can prove valuable in ensuring public safety when more sophisticated equipment fails. Similarly, amateur radio operators can use the code during weather emergencies to solicit information from outside the affected area. The news is relayed by them, by which they can keep people safe and informed. New communication technologies will continue to emerge, meanwhile Morse code, with its lack of sophistication, could remain just as effective an asset.
passage_title: Morse Code in the Modern Age

passage_text:
On a concrete <u id="q61">pillar just a few meters from the Eiffel Tower,</u> painted letters spell out, "This is not a photo opportunity."On the sands of the Bristol Channel, a <u id="q62">large, spray-painted, "X"</u> promises buried treasure. <u id="q63">On the side of a building in London, a stenciled image depicts a pair of uniformed soldiers</u> painting a vibrant red peace sign. Although nearly no one knows what this artist looks <u id="q64">like, there</u> are many who know his work. Blending sharp-tongued social commentary with humor and <u id="q65">whimsy British-born artist, Banksy,</u> has made a name for himself by challenging people's perceptions of the relevance of street art. 

<u id="q66">In the beginning, </u> Banksy's fame originated on the streets of Bristol, England, in the early 1990s. Under the cover of the night sky, Banksy worked quickly and steadily, sometimes painting freehand, sometimes spray-painting elaborately detailed stencils. <u id="q67">  </u>  

Concerned residents argued that Banksy's work was simply graffiti that encouraged vandalism. <u id="q68">that</u> encouraged vandalism. Others praised it as art done by and for the people and <u id="q69">debated</u>  for more. England's strict anti-graffiti policy meant that most of Banksy's pieces were destroyed within mere hours <u id="q70">of there</u> completion. <u id="q71">  </u>

By the end of the decade, Banksy had expanded his influence, painting his messages in places well beyond the British border. Seemingly <u id="q72">he is</u> everywhere and nowhere at once, Banksy had the full attention of the art world. Museum directors organized Banksy exhibitions, and <u id="q73">auctioneers sold actual pieces of buildings</u> that bore Banksy's artistry. In Banksy's own words, 

Despite his popularity, Banksy has not given in to the hype. He does not reproduce and sell prints of his images for profit. He also continues to communicate with the public through his street art, which is possible in part because he has managed to keep his identity secret. In Banksy’s own words,

<u id="q74">"Art is not like other culture because its success is not made by its audience."</u>
